title: 113_hr2375
content: The Act titled "Transparency and Accountability in Medicare Bidding Act of 2013" delays the implementation of the Medicare DME competitive bidding program and the national mail order program for diabetic testing supplies. The Act delays the implementation of the DMEPOS competitive bidding program and the national mail order competition for diabetic supplies until December 31, 2013. It also postpones the start of round 1 recompete of the bidding program. An evaluation of the bidding program will be conducted by an auction expert team. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will contract an auction expert team to review and assess the DMEPOS competitive bidding program. The team will evaluate aspects such as design, implementation, support for Medicare beneficiaries, market fairness, and sustainability. The auction expert team for the DMEPOS competitive bidding program will be selected through a competitive process. Disqualifications include being a current or former employee or contractor of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services involved in the program's design, lacking experience in government auction implementation, and lacking appropriate educational credentials. The auction expert team for the DMEPOS competitive bidding program must have appropriate educational credentials. The Secretary will provide all relevant information to the team, including details on the program's design and previous bidding rounds. The team must submit a report to the Secretary and Congress within 4 months, identifying any potential problems with the program. The DMEPOS competitive bidding program requires a review of HCPCS codes, assessment of access to items and services, analysis of health outcomes and costs, and identification of causes for any issues. The DMEPOS competitive bidding program requires an evaluation of the quality of items and services provided, costs of preventable hospitalizations, and identification of winning bidders and beneficiaries fulfilled annually. The DMEPOS competitive bidding program evaluates suppliers annually for calendar years 2010, 2011, and 2012. It identifies suppliers who failed to submit claims for more than 60 consecutive days and new suppliers added after January 1, 2011. Additionally, it identifies the number of Medicare beneficiaries served by each new supplier in competitive bidding areas. The program also requires identification of product categories and suppliers in round 1 re-bid and round 2. In round 2 of the DMEPOS competitive bidding program, key details include the number of winning suppliers, the number of new suppliers, the total Medicare beneficiaries served by winning suppliers, the estimated capacity to serve beneficiaries, and the total capacity bid by suppliers. The report on the DMEPOS competitive bidding program will include the total capacity bid by winning bidders and recommendations for program changes based on identified problems.
